Yes, it is certainly frustrating to consider the long history of discrimination and injustice that existed in the United States. The systemic racism that was so prevalent for centuries is a complex problem that cannot be reduced to any single factor, but there are a few key ways that people have justified or rationalized their discriminatory attitudes and actions in the past.

One of the most common justifications for discrimination was the idea of white supremacy. Many people, particularly those in power, believed that white people were inherently superior to people of other races, and that this superiority justified the subjugation of non-whites. This belief was reinforced by pseudoscientific theories that attempted to prove the supposed racial hierarchy, despite having no basis in fact.

Another common justification for discrimination was the idea of "separate but equal." This idea held that it was acceptable to segregate different races as long as the separate institutions were equal in quality. This, of course, proved to be a farce in reality, with segregated institutions frequently lagging far behind their non-segregated counterparts, and separate being anything but equal.

Finally, fear and ignorance played a major role in perpetuating discriminatory attitudes. People who had little or no contact with people of different races or cultures often developed misconceptions and stereotypes, which they then used to justify their actions. In some cases, fears about economic competition or political power led people to cling even more tightly to their discriminatory beliefs.

Overcoming these prejudices and addressing systemic racism remains an ongoing challenge, but it's important to remember that progress has been made and that there is always hope for a better future.
